												The game should be subtitled: "The Shakespearean Tragedy That Will Keep You Up At Night"This game is like an abused stepchild that nobody wants and everyone treats horribly. It's a shame to, since beneath the bloody, bruised, scarred surface, there's a gaming masterpiece hidden away!Confused yet? Let me explain.This game dates back to 2005 (ish) and was released in Asia at that time. It was successful enough there to warrant a NA/EU release several years later around 2010. This is still the same game engine, so short of some localization work, if the graphics look dated, there's a reason for it.That part isn't the tragic tale though. This game was able to pride itself on it's behind the scenes mechanics; player economy, crafting, PvP, skills, trading and sailing are all well thought out in depth.When this game was released, nations mattered. Each playable nation was as powerful and influential as the sum of its players. Ports would only open up after a nation had enough influence in the area... and the game world is HUGE. And this actually mattered to the player. Want to craft cannons? Hopefully your nation is in good relations with the port that sells iron!Then, a couple years later, dungeons were introduced for those claiming there was nothing to do in terms of the "Adventure" skill set. Of course dungeons have rewards, and those came in the form of rare exotic goods that can be sold for huge profits and a lot of experience.If you're wondering what dungeons and their loot (and money/exp bonuses) are doing in a game that's supposed to be about sailing, exploration and piracy, you're not alone.Netmarble was the publisher at the time and when people started to complain about side-lining all other skills and activities for dungeon-running, the most profitable and least risky, their answer was to increase the number of gold for sale in the cash shop!?Right about that same time, the CEO of Netmarble was arrested for some in-game currency selling scheme he and another employee were suspected of. At worst, it means the game's publisher had a CEO that was readily willing to find ways to profit off of the in-game currency, which was now reaching the ridiculous billion ducat (in-game-dollar) amount, surpassing anything the banks in the game were designed to handle. At best, it meant Netmarble was too preoccupied with the legal hassle to care about the game one way or another. So Uncharted Waters Online suffered either from active abuse or pure neglect.OGPlanet then took it over a couple years down the road. I think the term, "Too little, too late" readily applies to the current state of the game and anything OGPlanet has done/intends to do.This game was about the individual player finding ways to help their nation beat other nations in economic struggles, much like history shows occurred in the period the game portrays. THIS was the draw of this game; the active involvement of players in a part of global history. Due to abuses, exploits and neglect that went unchecked for years, this major feature of the game has gotten lost under the muck that's become the game's current state.The final nail in this game's coffin comes at the ease of the solution to all of this, that OGPlanet will not budge on; starting a new server. Given the high-end money-sinks they plan to implement and the in-game profits they plan on managing better, a new server would be the breath of fresh air this game needs. They've made it very clear, however, that they don't plan on doing this.Right now, if you're a new player, that 15,000 Ducat profit you made on a successful trade run will never amount to anything approachable to the 750,000 you can gain by spamming the starter level dungeon in half the time it took to make the one trade run.This game is broken, period. After 4 years of it's NA lifespan, nothing worthwhile has ever been done to fix that. New players will come and go, few will actually stay; my friend's list is proof of that as it's filled with nothing but inactive players from years past.Unless you hear of a new server starting, or a reset coming, avoid the heartache of playing this game. The drama this game has seen in its life will cause most dedicated gamers nightmares!Update:The problem, this game has in its current state (and I'll add this so people know this is still an updated review) is that the numbers don't add up.You can enjoy this game for the first 30 or so levels of a skill, before you get an advanced skill such as shipbuilding or spice trading. The game's fun and everything seems well balanced. Advance past the "school" tutorial though and the game takes a drastic turn for the worst.The more advanced, in-game methods for earning money still don't add up to the prices players sell their crafted items for. When you do a real time, 2 hour trade run to earn about 2-3 million ducats and find a simple accessory for your ship, that only adds 1 or 2 points above what the $50,000 ducat NPC equivalent costs, will run about 10 million ducats... the game is broken.When player made items are STILL selling for the billion ducat range and the above-mentioned methods of in-game earning only net a couple million at a time, providing you don't get attacked by NPC and player pirates, catch fire, infested by rats, etc... the game is broken.There's no out-flow of player money. There are plenty of ways to make it, but few ways to spend it that allow it to actually leave the game. The same money that flooded and crashed the game's economy is still floating around the game. There are no... or not nearly enough... in-game expenses to remove this. Ammo, crew, food, repairs, all cost a certain amount, but they don't cost millions to replace, only a few thousand. This game literally had BILLIONAIRES coming out of the woodwork when they screwed the pooch with dungeons and EA goods. Since then, neither Netmarble nor OGPlanet have done anything to actively remove this extra money form the game. They've "nerfed" the source of the income, but the money still exists. With that money being in game, prices will still be FUBAR... as demonstrated in the player bazaars.Although it's an open-world game, it's still an MMO. MMOs need goals and right now, this game destroyed those. A new player starting out will never, ever, in any realms of Hell, have any chance of ever being on the same playing field as the 5+ year vets who abused the system in the past. That right there, spells the death on an MMO. As I mentioned and others have confirmd, the early levels sees a large group of active players, but those numbers slow down as the levels get higher... once people realize the cards are stacked against them.I'm saying this as a warning for anyone willing to try this game for the first time: you will not last. Don't let the first few days in-game fool you. You will never be able to compete with the players who took advantage of the broken system years ago.Other than that, yes, the game has some incredible details. That's what drew me in and had me playing for 2 years initially. The days, ocean swells, storms, random events, skills, etc. all suck you in while you're doing something that would be boring in most other games. Catching a rare fish while sailing to South America, for instance. Being right outside of port and getting caught in a major storm. Having your ship suffer from plague, get infested with rats and cacth fire twice as you pass the Straits of Magellan is an experience you NEED to experience in this game. Other games just don't even comapre with this level of realism and authenticity.The game had everything going for it, but its management ruined it all. It causes actual pain for me to think about this potentially great game... and it's tragic downfall. It's the game all MMOs should strive to be, but greed got in the way.

												If I were reviwing only the game, I would not hesitate to give it 4 stars. The large open world with countless ports to explore and trade at, the many types of ship to sail, and the deep storyline blending historical accuracy with fantasy is very well done. This is no surprise coming from KOEI who are well known for their deep simulations and stories.The graphics, while dated, serve the game well and each port has a recognizable flavor to it. With many job titles across three archetypes (adventure, trade, and combat) and skill trees for all three, players have great flexibility in how to customize their characters to suit their own playstyle. Many games make this claim, UWO is one of the few to actually back it up with ample content for all career paths, and the game experience does not culminate in endless repetetive pvp. I would give four stars, not five, witholding one for some unclear writing and a cumbersome system for helping others with quests.The playerbase in my experience has been mature, polite and helpful, and the premium content shop is not game breaking. This is not a pay to win game.However, the inclusion of Nprotect GameGuard singlehandedly trumps any and all good points of the actual game (and there are many!) Gameguard advertises itself as an anti-cheat software, but installs itself as a rootkit. You are required to disable any antivirus software, because  gameguard behaves exactly as a virus. This leaves you with no protection while playing an online game, and is unacceptable from a security and common sense view. Even if it worked as intended, this would be unacceptable, but looking over the complaints on the forum make it clear this software does far too much harm, and any claims of it doing any good ar eimpossible to prove. Is the game free of cheaters because of gameguard? Or is it free of cheaters because it is an old game with dated graphics and requires  a reasonable intelligence and attention span to play? Finally, uninstalling the game will NOT remove gameguard, this requires manual removal, instructions can be found via google.Pros:Decent graphics, music and atmosphere.Rich world, dialogue and flavor text, quests have actual storylines to them.Actual content for all play styles, not merely a pvp funnel.Long voyages actually feel like long voyages (This can be good or bad)A freemium game that is NOT pay to win!Cons:Unable to walk around your shipInstalls rootkit on your computer.Customer support has been all but abandoned.Bottom line: If it ever removes the rootkit, its absolutely worth playing. Until then, avoid like the plague.

												I have a lot to say but keep in mind it's from the perspective of a solo PVE player that has seen far from everything. I'll get right down to what I like and don't like.Pros:- The three classes (adventurer, soldier, trader) are distinct, with their own unique abilities. Further, the subclasses (jobs) that you can choose from promote skills, which encourages finding your niche and working on it. This makes for a good sense of progression, character uniqueness and a broad selection of playstyles. For combat there is naval and land, ranged and melee; and adventurers have a range of playstyles, from collecting data around the world, to hunting down shipwrecks, and going on long voyages to make discoveries. Apart from freeform gameplay, there are also semi-randomised quests.-  The world is vast and there's a lot to see. You won't see all the content for hundreds of hours of gameplay. It's not derivative, either - it's awesome when you unlock a new part of the world to explore.- So many different ways to play. There's something for everyone. Adventuring is about long voyages, discoveries and treasure-hunting; maritime and land battles have some options and depth to them; trading is for more patient money-hoarding players with good knowledge of the trade lanes and goods, as well as inventory management.- Plenty of depth in the gameplay, you're always learning more tricks of the trade such as which consumables you're going to need to combat events at sea, or you can pick up skills to do that, or even set an aide to do it for you if they have the appropriate skills. You have many options in character-building and higher levels open up more possibilities.Cons:- The grind. Yeah, getting to the ''endgame'' (top-of-the-line ship and most advanced class) will take many, many hours. Although in this case, it's more about the journey than the destination. This isn't the type of game where you have to be endgame to get access to the worthwhile content. - The tutorials take hours. Seriously, you're looking at 10+ hours to get through all the schools. You don't have to, and you can go your own way at any time and come back later. Still, they are worth doing for the rewards despite the backtracking and awkward dialogue.- Documentation is poor. A lot of things in the game are not self-explanatory, and you won't find written help ingame. I've played for dozens of hours and I still couldn't tell you all the differences between Recog, Search and Observe skills. The good news is, it's not necessary to know every game mechanic. You pick whatever playstyle you want and you learn as you go. Also, the ingame community is very friendly and helpful.- Pay2Win elements. I'm not all that qualified to explain this since I don't play competitively, but there is at least one item that gives you an advantage over other players in the open seas (which are pvp zones): 30% speed boosters. That's huge, and I suspect it can be used to allow even the most sluggish pirate to hunt down even the speedist newb player. Sounds like a doozy. Thankfully, you can chart a course that takes you far from the major sealanes and the coast, for a good chance of avoing player pirates. Still, items like that are disconcerting. Also, buying a monthly subscription (about 15 dollars. Or Euros... hm...) gives you a fat paycheck in ingame currency. I don't know whether to put this under pay2win or not, but I guess if you're seeking pvp, yeah it would allow the subscribed player to get expensive gear sooner. So in my experience, UWO is great if you're after a PVE experience with a Renaissance maritime flavor. I know you don't get many options for that rubric, but it's good. I can't vouch for the pvp however, and you should be prepared for a long (if not steep) learning curve.

												After about a week or so playing this game, here are my impressions.Let's get this out of the way first: past masters, Netmarble, ruined this game by introducing a flawed dungeon system which sank the economy...many people have mentioned this in other reviews. Happily, new masters, OGPlanet have fixed this, and have presided over the renaissence of this game, including it's launch on Steam, which has seen a resurgence in player numbers, with many new folk (such as myself) joining the game of late. Problems relating to dungeons are gone and everything is a lot more balanced and fair.Right, on to the actual gameplay: one word - DEEP. This is an extremely detailed, almost dense game. Think EVE on the sea if you want an analogy. It's slower-paced and more thoughtful than your average "kill 10 boars, then kill 20 bats" type of MMORPG. There are 3 main skill tree branches under classes for Adventuring, Trading and Maritime (soldier) You can have skills from each. You are not restricted to only trading if you choose merchant at character creation, for example.The Trading aspect is deep and complex, incorporating an excellent crafting system where you can make products from raw materials; make sausages, ham and leather from pigs, tailor your own clothes, design and build your own ship etc.The Adventuring aspect is all about exploration and discovery, incorporating a complete world map where undiscovered cities are added as you discover them. Hunt for treasure in dungeons and ruins, dig up artifacts, indentify new species of animal. There's too many things to list here.The Maritime aspect is where it falls down a bit in my opinion. It's basically the same as other naval or pirate MMOs such as Voyage Century Online and Pirates of the Burning Sea. It's fun, sure, but it's not really my bag. That being said there's a large amount of options and customization as far as cannon, type of shot, melee battle tactics and items and land battle combat to get to grips with.The biggest downsides are the games somewhat dated visuals, serviceable, but nothing too fancy. (on the plus side, this means the game runs on potato-power PCs with no problem) and the tutorial system, which is very long compared to most run-of-the-mill MMORPGs these days. However, I reccommend doing the tutorial quests instead of skipping them, as you will get free ships and gear from completing them, as well as a good amount of money and skills by the time you graduate from the advanced level course in each of the 3 class courses.Last thing to mention is the community. This is easily the friendliest online community I have experienced in a long time. The School chat channel is full of helpful and friendly people ready to answer your questions. This is a blessing, as the game is extremely complex.Overall this is a fun and original game which offers a breath of fresh air from all those "cookie cutter" MMORPGs. It's deep and complicated, but rewarding for those who stick with it past the over-long tutorial.

												UWO is a game that has a lot of depth but takes up a lot of time, so if you do not have the time, do not read further.Uncharted Waters Online is a fairly old MMO that has been out for a while. I personally played it intensively for a year (when it was under Netmarble and when it was exclusively available on the OGP launcher) before I had to quit due to real life commitments. It is a great game that has a lot of depth due to complex mechanics and the reliance on knowing a lot of things if you want to do it the best way. However, the complexity and the gruelling tutorial system (that feels like real-like work) keep potential players away. Please, I urge you to try to get past it and see the game from an intermediate player's point of view. I know that I initially thought the game was boring during school but grew on me once I kept on playing.If you are looking for a great trading experience online while interacting with others, you are right at home! Even from the beginning, you are introduced to a commodity system similar to stocks (like in Port Royale) with lots of numbers. You can start fresh, trading between Dover and London and etc then eventually work your way to a long-distance Nanban trading routes such as Nagasaki (Japan) <-> London (England). Watching your character grow and your coffers fill up with money is the most satisfying thing in this game. I could say a thousand things about this but you will have to see for yourself. Be warned though, this does take a lot of real-life time so be wary of real life commitments.The combat is great but I have to admit that it is getting aged. The most amount of satisfaction you will get from the combat is beating other players rather than the combat system being great in of itself. It is a basic system of control your ship, choose ammo, and sink/board the enemy ship. I always found the system to be secondary to trade and more important towards the late-game for Epic Sea Feuds (massive player naval combat battle events), pirate hunting, etc. The bottom line is, it is great but don't have too high expectations. It is great FOR ITS TIME.It has a ton of neat features you wouldn’t see in many modern MMOs. Want a customizable apartment with a steward? Done. Want to have cool ships that you saw in those pirate books or movies that you dreamed of? You’re right at home. Want a companion character that helps you perform your job (trading, crafting, pirating, or whatever it may be) and can be dressed up/renamed for your every little fetishes? Done deal. Where have you seen a game with literally over a hundred cities and the world size that takes you half of real-life to go around? It is truly a gem that needs to be appreciated more.The community for the most part is very dedicated and friendly. If you can meet their expectations and be dedicated yourself, they will love you and you will love them. If you are looking for a great experience playing a slow-paced MMO you can sink your time into and make a lot of long-term friends, you will like UWO. However, if you are looking for a more faster paced MMO with emphasis on action-packed PvP and PvE raiding combat, you may want to look at a more modern MMO. This is an old-school MMO that does not hold your hand and it is up to you to stand up on your feet and reach up to it.tl;drThis game is good, give it a try.Be warned that it is a time vampire.Say goodbye to the outside.

												I've played this game on and off for a few years now and am glad it's come to Steam, if a bit late. Comparing it to other mmorpgs, I'd say the difficulty level is a little more challenging than most. KOEI is known for making historically accurate games and this one is no exception. While it was released to asian markets only for the first several years, it has been available for the rest of the world for the past several. It's as old as Word of Warcraft, but is free-to-play. Also something to note, it is *not* pay-to-win, like some f2p games are. Some of the best items/ships are potentially/statistically superior, it isn't such a noticable difference, unless in the hands of an unskilled/inexperienced player. And there are a LOT of ships to suit your playstyle. Concerning playstyles, there are 3 major ways to play the game, and you can change it up as you see fit without too much hassle. Adventuring, Trading, and Battling. Adventurers have probably the closest to a single-player experience as you can get on an mmo, and won't be disappointed with the historical discoveries, locations and treasures that come from diligence. Trading is probably one of the easiest tasks, and is practiced by every player-type. Many different trade goods from various regions of the world and a very deep economic structure that changes prices of goods depending on supply/demand and trading tendencies of other players. Maritime (sea battles) is one of the more appealing features to newcomers and seasoned players alike, and UWO has probably the best sea-battle gameplay around.PVP exists in the majority of sea zones throughout the world but only the truly skilled maritimers can benefit from a life of piracy on the high seas. I've been pirated only a handful of times in the years I've played and it should be noted that it isn't something to deter you from going where you want to go. There is a healthy balance to all things.As for the community of players, some of the nicest and most helpful players abound here! There are so many intricacies to the gameplay, I still learn something new daily, and nearly everyone has an answer or an idea to help you along. We're really all in it together! Instead of "guilds" like other mmorpgs of a historical era, there are Companies. Each is a maximum of 50 players. This is a great way to keep the members tight with each other, and promotes a feeling of having an 'extended family' instead of just other gamers.If you are a fan of ridiculous amounts of loot and items, then you will be disappointed. There are a ton of items in the game, but space is always your enemy.. or friend? You gotta know what to keep and what to sell/discard. It's good to keep that greed in check.Pros: Great community of players. Deep and challenging gameplay. Developers did their homework when it comes to history and facts. Educational and relaxing, solid variety in all things, in-game achievements (memorial album/challenge missions). Prioritization is an optional skill you involuntarily acquire that is helpful in life. :D. Locations, player models/outfits, ships, sailing, and even the music(which I mute to listen to radio) still has a unique charm.Cons: Grinds (it's a game created by Asians!). Somewhat frustrating interfaces that seems to have a higher learning curve. Only 1 message window for all information in game, be it chat, announcements, crafting, battle...everything. I still gripe about wanting another window to keep conversations separate from everything else. Graphics are a bit dated, if that is important to you.I could go into much more detail about specifics, but this is already longer than I intended. So, as far as free-to-play mmorpgs go, and even comparing it to subscription mmorpgs and the multitude of games I've played throughout my existence on this planet, I'm going to rate it a solid 7/10.I hope to see some of you there.

												The most common reasons this game is hated are the following:Uses third party DRMExtremely tedious(At the beginning)The prior is admittedly an issue, however the latter is misunderstood.Uncharted Waters Online is an extremely relaxing game. When you begin the game you have to make the choice between becoming a fighter, a trader, or an adventurer.*KEEP IN MIND THAT THIS DECISION DOES NOT DETERMINE YOUR ENTIRE GAME, YOU CAN CHANGE BETWEEN CLASSES AT ANY TIME, AND THERE ARE BENEFITS TO DOING PRECISELY THAT.*-A fighter, as you might imagine will battle AI ships for the majority of their time playing, and will eventually enter PvP where they can have a lot of fun if you enjoy PvP. There are MASSIVE rewards to playing in PvP events.-A trader does not JUST trade, they also craft non-purchaseable master level items that players can use. For example: extremely powerful hulls, extremely powerful cannons, and extremely good sails. The majority of the in-game economy revolves around these items.-Finally, the adventurer. The adventurer does not have any actual purpose in PvP or money making, as it is out done by the fighter and trader respectively. *HOWEVER* The adventurer has the *FASTEST* ships, and discovering and doing adventure quests can be extremely fun if you have the patience, Albeit as tedious as the other 2 classes with less rewards.Now, most players who complain about the game being too tedious have never actually completed the tutorial (key word MOST) I understand that many will find the length of the "tutorial" extremely absurd. However, keep in mind this game is absolutely massive and extremely complex, so knowing all the information, at the very least the basics, will benefit you massively if you intend to keep playing. The game also rewards you MASSIVELY if you complete the tutorial, with good mid-level ships and nearly a million of the ingame currency being given to you, practically just for reading text.Contrary to what some believe, the tutorial is COMPLETELY SKIPPABLE, it is NOT MANDATORY IN ANY WAY SHAPE OR FORM, but if you don't do it, it is likely you will be even more upset with not knowing what you're doing than you would have been if you had simply completed the tutorial. However if you feel your odds are better by trying your luck by yourself, by all means, please do that.The majority of the community is extremely helpful. I recommend attempting to join a Company as soon as possible, but School Chat is extremely helpful as well. If you have a problem, let people in school chat know.

												I've been a huge fan of Koei's games since way back in the SNES / Super Famicom days.  Though I haven't played this one through steam, I have logged over 1k hours on and off over the last few years.  This game at it's core really is a good adaptation of the Uncharted Waters series into an MMO. The original version, launched in Japan in 2005 as a subscription based game,  looks like it's close to what I would consider an ideal MMO for a simulation junkie.  And that is what makes the version published here in the west such a bitter disapointment.  The after market cash shop they tacked on cheapens every aspect of the game.  It turns what was designed to be a repetitive but rewarding experience into an all out slog, a slog that spending 50 USD per month barely mitigates.  Many systems have been nerfed or slowed down from the original design in order to coerce players into whipping out a credit card to speed them back up.  The game is set up to have an incredibly robust player economy where all the best ships and items are crafted by players.  Top tier items in this version come only from the cash shop. Powerful ships better than anything a player can make come only from their lottery box. Certain recipes are cut from the crafting proffesions entirely so the items they make can be sold for cash.  Most of these items are tradable in game, but the fact that players can not make them on their own ruins most of the charm and intent of the design.It is possible to get somewhere that resembles "end game" without forking over a fortune, but to do so would involve putting yourself through thousands of hours of doing nothing in game but grinding resources.  During this time you'll be repeatedly zoomed passed at sea and destroyed in combat by newer players that shelled out a couple hundred bucks for their ships. Ships were supposed to be a part of character progression, they have level requirements to sail.  Even the highest end cash shop ships have level requirements so low that they can be reached in a couple weeks of play. I can't reccomend this game but there is a lot here to like. Insanely complex systems, trading, dungeon running, exploration, naval combat, a combination of skill based and level based advancement, layers and layers of systems you'll still be discovering and figuring out hundreds of hours after you start.    If you've got a high tolerance for repetition you can get to "competitive" levels of gear and ships and money without taking out a second mortgage on yoru house, but you'll likely never make it to a true end game on completely equal terms with those that spend thousands. The in game markets are all dominated by players juggling in game money and cash. The high end naval battles are dominated by players who spend hundreds of dollars on their character development and ships.  If you started from scratch and only ran one account it would take years to begin approaching established players like that, and that's assuming you know the game and can play efficiently.  Still, if you really need a hobby and have a big chunk of disposable income and / or a few thousand hours to spare this game might be worth checking out.  If you're like me the more you learn about it the more disappointed you'll be, but there is some fun to be had.  Particularly if you don't mind multiboxing 3+ accounts and have a core group of friends that did the same, you could accomplish a lot in this game and have a blast.  If Koei stopped liscensing this thing out to 3rd rate lottery box companies and gave us the option to play the subscription model I'd be there in a heartbeat.  I'd also start from scratch if Koei ever puts out a first - party international free server with a more balanced approach to the cash shop and what they sell in itI've got a real love / hate relationship with this thing.  I'm not sure if there's any real solutions for all the problems caused by the tweaking of the game around the cash shop, and making the game require a subscription would totally annihilate the already tiny player base.  While the review paints a picture of the game being completely "pay 2 win"  free players and small time spenders can get a decent game out of it, especially power gamers that run multiple accounts and exploit every mechanic and design flaw that they can.  It's frustrating because 1/3rd of the game or more is designed as an economics / trading simulation and that gameplay is mostly circumvented by players generating their money from selling things out of the cash shop.  The upshot is that most of the stuff in the cash shop is available for in game currency if you can find a seller at least.  I think the whole "lottery box" model is a terrible pyschologically manipulative business as well, hooks gambling addicts like no other.  Anyway just ranting now, I'm leaving the review as thumbs down but as I mentioned there is still a decent game here and if you love the age of sail, pirates, plunder, exploration, discovery, and in game economies it's worth taking for a spin, assuming you're ready for an epic grind.  I'd suggest that if you spend money at all you wait until you really understand the game, I watched power hungry new players getting ripped off every day in the trade channels.  The learning curve is too high to get any value out of early game cash purchases, and when you do start to understand the game you'll realize the value of most of the digital junk they sell is very low.

If you are at all interested in ships or playing a different kind of game that isn't a Diablo or WOW clone this is for you. A lot of the game isn't fast paced but i enjoy that aspect. The high points of the game are; lots of things to do, very unique sailing experience, being a pirate, fighting pirates, escaping from pirates, well done economy, runs great on low end systems, you can play and enjoy the full game without spending real money, freedom, PVP (consenting and otherwise), rum, discovering intriguing things in history, many ships types to sail, regularly updated, the company that runs the server is engaged in the game, many dedicated and helpful players. Low points are; quite a bit to get orientated to on the start, little in game info (use uwodbmirror.ivyro.net and the uwo wiki to find things), graphics are decent but not modern (doesn't bother me), there are some fantasy and blatantly historically innaccurate aspects, npc characters are not inspiring.Explanation of the three job types. Also you can mix and match skills from any and switch about all you like so don't feel like you have to commit to one solely. Maritime: battle orientated. This can be from fighting to take over cities and ports in epic sea feud to fighting pirates to being a pirate. You can fight on ships, on land, in arenas, duel, use guns, cannons, swords, bows, knives, explosives and many other assorted goodies.Trade: Fairly like you'd expect. Buy low sell high or craft things. Best way to make money in the game. There are "local specialty goods" in the game. You get more money and experience by taking these goods to ports farther and farther away from where they are produced. Some of these can be crafted from raw materials increasing profit even more Adventure: seeking out new discoveries. This encompasses a lot. Discoveries can be anything from hidden treasure, to anient cities, to geography, to sunken ships, to art or religious artifacts, to exotic animals and new locations. You find what is interesting to you and there is a lot to find. Most of the things you find are actually historic items or places ect which is fun for me being a history buff but you don't have to be one to get satisfaction from finding the stuff.

												An old established gigantic game. You can't win, can't lose, it goes on forever and you never find all the paths to follow. You play it as a long-term hobby, so most of the 100+ on-line at any time are dedicated nurds, mostly adults, more than half female, who have been playing for years. The kind of people who do the hard crosswords every day. So there's an established community. You can't really play well without friends, community help, hand-me-downs, and frequently referring to on-line forums and cribs. You'll keep notebooks and write stuff down because there's too much to remember. You'll run more than one character ('toon) because the game is so big, so deep and there are too many avenues to explore. It's like a maze, but there's no correct path, no short-cut to success and time passes slowly. You need patience. Satisfaction comes from a million little achievements, tiny hops along your chosen route, referred to as "the grind". Older players will help you along.You can become a pirate, or a pirate hunter, but that takes a lot of time and money. You'll only hear about them, but probably not see one, for many months into the game. You start in a nursery area between England and the Mediterranean and attend up to nine schools for tutorial lessons. You do trading, questing, producing, map-making, policing and discovering while building your skills here before being allowed out to the wider world. Then things escalate. To join the big guys you'll need to work hard, and to form a gang for self-protection with your friends. Planning you toon's life is part of the fun. There are monthly sea-battles, races and other events you can join if you want to compete with other players but these are not compulsory.I recommend this game if you have the tenacity, patience and focus to play. It's not for instant teenage solo heros. Try and join with a friend as you can help each other, share tasks, reinforce each other's skills. Lately there have been more returning players than new blood, as people come back to the game after years away. Says something about the endless quest mentality of players perhaps. Also says how good the game really is. Forget the fact that the graphics are from 15 years ago and the translations from the original japanese are sometimes enigmatic because the game is a puzzle in your head, not a video experience. It's a life-style game. Choose a life, a job, an expertise, a body, a costume - I've never seen two people dressed the same. 												Quick summary before a point-by-point review of the good and bad.UWO is a by now 10+ year old (so expected dated graphics, design conventions et.c.) game of the age of sail. Think Sid Meier's Pirates if you're not familiar with the superior Uncharted Waters series before, but on a worldwide scale with absolutely no ballroom dancing, guaranteed. Knowledge of real world geography will help you here. It's an open-ended game, but without the common pitfalls of "what do i do now?" of sandbox games. It's very much "pick your playstyle" sort of ordeal. An explorer who wants to profit of far-away trade? A trader who carries less but knows which way to hold a sword? A bounty hunter? Mix and match freely.The largest problems in this game are;- The absurd monetization. If i understood it correctly, a few of them are normal features on the Japanese release of the game, although their version last i checked required one-time payment. The monetized items include your bank (timed 30 days), speed buffs, questionably powerful items and more.- The "anti-hacking tool" malware that you'll bump into if you dare to play eastern games on your PC. In earlier versions, it was possible to remove it, but it frequently causes severe issues with input device drivers, particularly Logitech seems to be the target of the people who make this. This is what caused me to quit, and it took them more than a month to fix. I'm looking to play it again soonish, however.- Selectively poor design. In a nutshell, everything that you do on foot is poorly designed. Your mileage varies, but generally if you do go explorer, i'd advise against explorers who specialize in land missions (Biology, largely Archaelogy, et.c.) and instead choose Cartography and the likes.- Massive overinflation causing overtly screwed up economy due to money-gouging translation company (the previous one, though this current one isn't less gougey). Seriously, if you play normally with minimal player interaction, a million is a lot of money. If you trade with players for bog-standard dime a dozen items, 200-400k per item of a certain type is extremely cheap. It really needs a total reboot, or better yet, a remake.- If your goal is "max level now", forget it. That obsession will give you nothing but grind here.- Exposition-heavy tutorial with extremely janky sections. Blah blah blah, get on with it!- Questionable sensation of queasiness over the inclusion of child-like characters. If you can get over the sight in games like FFXIV-2 or TERA, you're fine here too. Personally, i cringe at the sight. Thankfully, the game does provide a button (escape, amusingly enough) to simply fade away all player characters. Blissful.Now, i firmly believe the good outweigh the bad.- Open class choices. Despite the game handing you out a starting class, you're more than free to change your job (trader,  warrior, explorer) at any time to any of the class-subtypes you have learned(i'm trying to keep the review brief-ish, so not explaining those here). The painful, drawn out tutorial does offer you more "class slips", and some players are fine with doing the tutorial (school) for them, and admittedly, the rewards are nice, but i prefer other ways of obtaining them.- Open progression. Each class comes with a tree. You're free to- and encouraged to mix and match the trees. Traders learn body language, for instance, which most all people probably get. Adventurers are more likely to learn the actual languages instead, especially languages which they need to read up libraries for discovery information.- Highly varied playstyles. Explorers, traders and warriors each play highly differently. Explorers don't largely care about mobs/mooks and more often than not outrun them if ambushed, traders fear the pirates deeply, and soldiers/warriors go in all cannons blazing. Explorers, well, spend their time exploring. Traders spend their time trading and applying their craft and trade, and soldiers do what you'd expect them to.- Non-AFK style sailing. Finally, instead of boring "oh, i guess i'll get a cup of coffee and entertain myself with an entertaining game while pretending to enjoy this other game i'm waiting on" that you see in so many games ranging from EvE(Low- and nullsec nonwithstanding, of course) to Elite, you need to respond to waves and changing winds in different manners depending on your sails, the ship, your abilities and so on. Of course, there's a skill to help you with this, but you still need to keep an eye on the game, steer your ship and so forth.- Considerable differences between water areas. You'll face different winds, different challenges and generally are encouraged to use different styles of ships for the different areas of the game. Mediterranian is an inland sea embraced by land, so you don't really have strong waves or strong winds, and even when you do, the winds are often blowing from the atlantic or northward, so moving westward would be commonly painful... Yet here, you're given the option of rowable ships, which you'll also see in the arabian sea later in the game. There are other flavors, like the huge waves and powerful winds in the atlantic, or wildly twisting winds of the pacific, but i'm struggling to keep this brief.- Generally really well done and thought out progression. While being the ultimate goal, reaching the maximum level or potential isn't your immediate desire or need. There's fun and (relatively, see hyperinflation) profitable activities to do from the moment you hop onto your ship. I never felt like i was in a rush of reaching the top level, and... despite clocking in 340 hours, i'm still not there, and i can certainly say i enjoyed most of those hours.- Magnificient soundtrack that cannot be praised too much. My ears have never been so pleased by consistent beauty. Each music piece in this oozes the thematics of the area or the nation you're in. Go check them out in google. Marseilles' theme brings to mind france, food, culture, snobbish, hro hro hro. While Oxford's theme is venerable, if slightly bombastic. Amsterdam is more easygoing, and London is very royal and quite reserved. The moment you hit africa's ocean the first time and that tune hits you, it's just chills all the way. There is no music here that stands out in good, or bad.Have a sample:

												I think I logged a few more hours than I intended to playing the game this week --- In fact I didn't even log off, I got booted off because they are doing 2 hour maintenance. What a great time to write a review! I really enjoy playing this game. Very in-depth! At first, I logged in and did schooling, which was pretty slow but I enjoyed it. After graduating all three beginner courses (Maritime, Adventure and Trade), the school gave me a decent ship and I bought some trade goods and hit some ports and made a little profit. I fought with pirates in the Caribbean, traded everything from alcohol, rope, chicken, agate and crystals and even discovered some lost relics and statues! You can learn skills like procurement (to catch water when it's raining), fishing, ballistics, accuracy, frugality (sailors use less rations), search, sail-handling and a ton of other skills (different languages so you can communicate with vendors in foreign countries).  It's really inspiring to go to a capital like Seville and see 50 player bazaars (vendors) selling luxurious hand-made dresses and clothes. armour or EU goods, furniture for your quarters or parts for your ship. Anything...  To tell you the truth, after 130 something hours this week I only scratched the surface of this game and haven't even done one dungeon yet!! But now that the server should be up in 15 mins or so (and I learned the basics from a friend, self sailing and school) I am ready to give one a go and hopefully get some valuable loot!If you haven't tried this game out - I strongly recommend you try it... Especially being free! It can be a little slower-paced than most MMORPG's I have played (starting off with nothing and learning the essentials) but I think it is more rewarding. Trust me, once you upgrade from your Barca or small boat to a Battle Heavy Caravel and have some decent cannons and a AIDE ship (or a trading vessel if you want!) and get into the action - you'll see the hours go by. Playing this game captured a little bit of my heart and I'm looking forward to where next week will take me... Or the month after.   :-))  But rest assured, I will be grinding on GAMA...  Barina from the Netherlands.

												Greetings, fellow gamers!Admittedly, I've stepped away from UWO for a bit, but I will say that when I am engaged...I am ENGAGED!  This game is not for the time constrained for faint of heart.  As a fan of the Koei NES versions of the game: UW and UW2, this is an excellent successor to the series.Gamer population: very helpful, with several differtent chats to choose from to seek guidance and help.  Several wiki's are available to support new gamers, or gamers that have fallen off the wagon.Personalization: one of the best aspects of this game is the ability to personalize your toon and your ship.  Want to look like certain captain from a movie/cartoon, you can!  Want to make your ship resemble historical pirate ships? Find the paint and sail and it's yours!Community content and indie adventures: Another plus.  The Game provides historical events the community and PC can participate in, which influence the game world, as well in-game non-aligned quests from quest hubs at the ports.  Random events and pirate attacks keep you on your toes as you negotiate the game mechanics.Not so good: The tutorial is PAINFUL. Long and cumbersome, but necessary, if you want to know how to do the basics.  With the availability of the wikis and the willingness of the online community to share, the burden on the player is somewhat removed.  Graphics: dated and cheesy, but it's Koei and I'm a bit sentimental, so I forgive it.  Others may not be so forgiving.Combat: the one-on-one duels can be frustrating if you don't have the right weapon/armor/tool mix to counter your enemy during boarding actions.  The land quests are fun, but can be just as frustrating.The gradual degeneration of your ships hit points: this is the most tedious aspect of the game for me.  I get a new ship,  and over the couse of voyages, encounter pirates, rival factions, storms and other randome phenomenon.  I can either fix myself or take to a pro in port.  Either way, the max HP level for my ship deteriorates.  I understand the historical truisms the game tries to maintain, but this one gets under my finger nails!By and large, this is a fun game, with lots to explore and do.  I'd say give it a spin and be willing to invest at least 20 hours to truely get a feel for it.

												Edit: Managed to get it working again (somehow), so I'm changing the review.UWO is very different from your average MMO, in no small part due to the majority of the game revolving around sailing the world and exploring, trading, or both. Upon starting, you're asked to pick a starting job from 3 choices: Adventurer (exploration), Trader (mercantile) and Battle (soldier). Each job has it's own skill set, and you're able to change jobs as you progress, so you're not just tied down to the one you pick at the beginning.Sailing itself is rather easy once you get the hang of it, which shouldn't take very long. The main threat when at sea is other players. Around the starting areas of Europe, you're relatively safe as long as you can deal with or avoid NPC pirates. But in other regions of the world, the titular uncharted waters, other vessles are free to attack you. Thankfully the world is a big place so encounters shouldn't be too often, plus you can group up with friends and have them help you out in a fight. Operating a merchant vessle and concerned about hostile ships? Bring along a soldier buddy to watch your back as you make trade runs.Overall the game is very fun to play. Points lost for the use of GameGuard, but hopefully that shouldn't be too much of a problem for many players.

Posted: November 11, 2014
												             Just short of 300 hours into this now and these are my impressions so far. Overall, I find the game enjoyable and even somewhat addictive. There's a great deal to do and many different paths to take to do it. While I can tell there is a consensus "best" way to get lots of money and the best equipment as soon as possible, I haven't felt forced into that play style to enjoy the game. I also haven't felt that the P2W element is very prevalent though that may come into play more as you progress. Actually for me the best part so far is that it's an MMO that you can easily play almost like a single player game if you wish. There's also plenty of opportunity for interaction with other players if you wish.               And that's where the major fault in the game lies as far as I'm concerned. The community is pretty much divided into new players mostly from the recent addition of UWO on Steam and people who have been playing for years. I'm sure this isn't a unique problem in MMOs. The experienced p[layers almost always are willing to answer game related questions but certainly have their established cliques and often dominate chat with personal feuds and erudite conversations that are more confusing to new players than anything else. Unfortunately the game's moderation at the moment seems to consist solely of fellow players who rarely intervene(and sometimes even participate) in the drama unless it involves chasing gold scammers. My advice would be to use the school chat while you are getting familiar with the basics and then turn off WC unless you need the entertainment. There are at least two helpful wikis available that can help with most questions you are likely to have and they don't engage in two plus hour name calling contests.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												This is a classic never ending MMORPG. You start out in school learning the basics of sailing, trading and combat and can choose any career path you want Adventuring, Trading, Combat (PVE or PVP) or a combination of all.Sounds good and for a while you'll enjoy it but then you find you've done everything you wanted to in a skill or field and have to move on to another skill or job or go insane with boredom, there is no point staying as an expert at something. Adventuring has huge scope with many different things to do, but unfortunately you will end up doing the same quests, hunting the same relics and raising the same shipwrecks over and over and over again.Trading is again fine at the start, if you choose to stay F2P you'll grind your way up the skills buying and selling everything you can for profit until you make it to East Asia to trade. Buy dirt cheap get back to eurpoe and sell items for a huge profit to NPC's or to other players for an even huger profit, but once you've done it a few dozen times its pales quickly.Combat in the game comes in two types, land or sea. Land combat is possibly the worst you will see in any modern MMO or possibly any game ever made, it is unbelieveable bad. The sea combat is better with fully buildable and modable ships it can be fun but again the missions are extremely limited and just attacking random NPC's hour after hour is amazingly boring.PVP Combat is the way most people go before quitting. You use the fortune you've amassed to buy a NC (cash shop real money) ship that has been modded with NC items go to a busy trading area (most areas in the game outside europe are PVP) and attack people in trading ships. They know you are coming so leave all ther money and good items in the bank leaving you just thier cargo to steal (you can't take thier ships or even items equipped on thier ships atm). The only problem is that thier cargo is bought in the area you are patrolling so is basically worthless unless you transport it yourself and your crew heavy combat ship uses all its cargo space for food to feed your sailors. So you sit there attacking people who don't fight back, mabye you like that kind of thing, I don't.Crafting is around par with the average MMO, grind you way up different skills (cooking for instance) until you get to rank 10, you then need to take a specialised job in that skill to get your rank higher. If you change your job you keep any xp you have gained in the skill but it can only be used at rank 10 until you take a specialised job again. Irritating as hell.The UI is abysmal. Every time the Devs add something to the game it is added to a drop down menu with no help or explanation as to what it is. The initial training in school is OK as long as you rmember it has been transated from Japanese by someone with poor english and there are huge errors, one instructor has his title translated three different ways, one above his head, one from his own mouth and one in the quest log. you haven't a clue whats going on. The mainline quests are even worse, you can be stuck in the middle of nowhere with no idea what to do next.I'm making it sound bad, I know. I played UWO for a few years as something different to my normal kind of game (DDO, LOTRO, SWTOR) before getting bored. I went back and lasted a month before dropping it again. I'm 2 weeks back into it and again bored, it seems to have reached its limit for me.If you are looking for a way to kill a couple of years without focus then try this. Almost everything in the game takes a LOOONG time so it can eat up empty days you have easily. The guides are all dreadful or translated from the games original Japanese release badly so you can spend hours trying to find even the simplest of information.There are a few good things about the game but they aren't game based. Most of the people in the game are friendly, it seems to be an entry level MMO and many haven't honed thier trolling skills yet. As the game has no real direction setting yourself personal goals and hitting them is also good.This is definately a pay-to-win game. OGP the people running it are money mad, you can buy anything and everything in the cash shop except accounts, look hard enough on the web and you can find them up for sale everywhere though. The account-email verification link is broken.I'm sitting here writing this as the game is down, again, OGP have been getting DDOS attacks lately. Everything they have is currently offline, a few days after they took everything down to 'fix the problem'. Nothing written on the facebook page and in fact nothing anywhere. OGP is definately a company where cash comes first, then thats it, no second or third. Players/customers have no input or say in anything.So my verdict on the game is simple, if you have never played an MMO of this type before give it a go. You will like its MMO freedom and the other players. Then when you are stuck (about 15 minutes in) go to a grown up game of this type like EVE. No rules, no direction and even though its P2P (a monthly pack in UWO is around 4 times the cost of a month in EVE), have a good first month and you can legally use in game money to pay for the game.If you have played MMO's of this type before then stay away, far away. It can suck you in as all games can and as you're a good player you can get over all the bad points but in two years time you'll find you've just wasted two years.Go to EVE, it costs but a lot less than this will, believe me I remember my bills. rant over.....

												Uncharted Waters Online is a MMO trade sim kind of game.  There are three distinct styles of gameplay you get to choose powers from to build your character.  Merchant, which involves going from port to port in your ship and carrying expensive goods between them for resell.  Combat, which involves running around and shooting at pirates for honour, glory, and lols.  FInally, there is adventure, which involves exploring land and fighting in hand to hand combat.At the start of the game, you choose a nation to be a part of.  Each one has a different starting location.  AFAIK, there is no wars, but you can raid your enemy nations without♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off your home one.   You are then dropped into the capital porttown of your homeland and told to visit the accademy.  The accedemy is a 40 hour long quest line that can be ignored if you wish, but it'll teach you EVERYTHING about the game, so I recommend running it!If you wish to become a pirate, you have two varities of "piracy" to choose from.  There is Privateer, which is a pirate with honour.  You are expected to only attack enemy nations, and to protect your own merchants if possible.  There is also Pirate, where you are not allowed to EVER return to your own nation and there is only one port in the entire world that will take you (and it's hidden!)Pirates can only attack in unguarded waters.  Waters outside of Europe are unguarded, but they will become guarded in each region when a pirate is killed there.  So pirate hunters can keep waters guarded and keep their freinds safe by simply sailing around and attacking any pirate they see.Pirates and privateers can be attacked at any time for no penalty and they're basically a walking target because it'll turn their names red and yellow, respectively.I end my review with a small tip for the merchants out there who don't understand the market rates.  The percentage is the percentage of the normal cost of the item.  So if it says that wool is 90%, and the cost is 90, for instance, that means the average price is 100 and you'll get it for 10% off.  If it says that wool is 150%, then you'll pay 150 coins for it.  The arrows next to the percentages tell what the last change to the price was, up or down.  Prices change.  If a lot of people buy wool, for instance, then the percentage will JUMP up to 160%, as an example.  You'll also get bonuses for delivering specialities far away from their home.  If you take some Irish whiskey to Venice, for instance, the venice merchants will pay you a ton for it, and if you take some spice from India to London, for instance, they'll pay you a ton for it.

												Right away you should know that this game is NOT for people who are impatient. It takes ages to get anything important done, and there is a LOT of grinding.That may sound like a negative, but really, this game makes grinding fun in oddly satisfying ways.You can choose from three main professions: adventurer, merchant or soldier (although you can do all three on the same character if you want, nothing's stopping you). The tutorial is very long, but only because there are a LOT of mechanics to this game that you need to know about before you set sail onto the open ocean. The complexity of this game's mechanics may discourage players who don't want a game that requires them to think about 15 different things at once. If you want a simple, low-effort game, this isn't for you at all.BUT if you are okay with that, what you'll get is an MMO with an absolutely enormous world to explore. Almost the entire Earth has been modelled in this game and unlocking/exploring the whole thing will take weeks, maybe even months out of your life that you'll likely never call wasted.Bottom line pros and cons:Pros: -Choose from six countries to represent: England, The Netherlands, France, Spain, Portugal or Venice.-An enormous game world to explore.-Exploration isn't only rewarded, it's kind of the whole point.-Absolute sandbox freedom straight from the start (although doing the tutorial is highly recommended).-Supportive and helpful community always happy to offer advice.-Fans of PVP can become pirates and hunt down defenceless merchant players in certain parts of the world.-Interesting and well-paced story.-Very educational. You'll learn a lot about history, geography, different types of ships and loads more.-The soundtrack can be very catchy and is usually very fitting to the environment.Cons:-Very grindy. The grinding isn't as monotonous as it is in some games, but a lot of your playtime will be spent grinding.-PVP is virtually unavoidable. Other players can attack you anywhere outside of Europe, and if you're not battle-oriented, you need to be on your toes at all times.-The player-run economy in this game is broken. A lot of even the most basic player-made items can be incredibly expensive.-Repairing damaged equipment and restoring a ship's maximum health can only be done using special items that are much harder to get than they should be considering how often you will need them.-The graphics, even on the highest setting, aren't anything to write home about.Overall, this game is very fun for fans of this style. This game will be appealing to those who like this sort of MMO. For those who want fast-paced games full of action, this probably isn't what you're looking for. But if you like games with large amounts of effort, thinking and detail that allow as much freedom as you want at a slow and comfortable pace, this game is definitely worth a try.8/10.

												I started playing this game as soon as it was released in North America. I have been playing it off and on since a few years ago. I'm not even close to polishing off any of the games content. You will never say you are done with the game because they continuously add content to it every month or few months.You can be an adventurer, tradesman, or a maritimer and you can switch from those classes anytime you want in the game; you are not stuck with one class your entire playthrough. For every class there are also job titles that you can be; you can switch any of these jobs anytime you want as well.The game is very in depth and it will take awhile to get started. But there's nothing like sailing the seven seas as soon as you are ready. Travel time is about where you want it from port to port. Sometimes it even takes too long honestly but it gives the game more of that realism feeling you've been wanting.  Skills are very important in this game. As a mater of fact, skills are a lot more important than your levels. A higher skill rating makes you better than the other player with a lower skill rating. Even if that other player is topped out on his levels and you are not; as long as your skills are higher the advantage goes to you. Levels are important for being able to ride certain ships, and unlocking certain quests. Skills impact every single little thing you do in the game.A lot of free to play games tell you they are free but they are really not. I'm talking about the games with addons, paid expansions, or you need to have a premium subscription to go somewhere in the game or do something in the game that a free player could not. Uncharted Waters Online content is completely free and you don't have to pay a dime. The only advantage paying gets you in UWO is clothes, ships, and consumable items. Expansions to your inventory, ship speed up, proficiency rate gaine, experience gain are other things you can pay but you don't need it because there is so much content in the game you will eventually level out everything without the help of boosters in the first place. You don't really need the expansions to your inventory because you can make as many alts as you want and store your items on them that don't fit your main character. The games content is completely free.The games community is very large and the game is gaining popularity as we speak.It is indeed a one of a kind game and I encourage anyone who loves to explore, sail the seven seas, or play for reward of playing to give it a go. Like, now.
